Yes, I do like the food here.  And the beauty is only five minutes walk from our home.  So I usually walk down to this beach in the morning for exercise or sometimes I may dip in the salt water.
So yes, this is Gambia.  We are home.  We relax.

yay Today is all about family.  On a Sunday everyone relax on the beach with their family because tomorrow is back to work.  So this is where people start to come and get a load off.  You swim, they play football on the beach.  Children, they're running around.

I'm Boubacar.  My name is Boubacar Barry.  I'm the eldest son of the late Suleyman Barry, the owner of Solomon's Beach Bar and Restaurant.  The restaurant started like this, as you can see in the picture.  And my dad started this, it's now 35 years since we had it.  So when my dad passed away, we took over the business and we transformed it to this.  So, it's a nice place.  It's Gambian-owned, local, and everything is original here.  Yeah, one lot.  Respect.

Just a couple of questions for you.  If, for example, someone was coming from the diaspora, and they wanted to maybe go to Sanyang or somewhere else to establish a hospitality business like this, would you encourage them to do it?

Yes, of course, I would.  I would encourage them, because I think there's a lot of potential in Gambia, and I think people should come back home and establish.  There are lots of chances and opportunities here.  I think so.

So what would you say has been the biggest benefit to you?  I know this is obviously a family business and one thing I do like about Gambia, we're here at family day on a Sunday, is the whole element of family and family cohesiveness.  So what I'd like to ask you is what has been the benefit of working as a family for you?

First, I would just say God bless my dad.  At least he's been a very hard-working man and he kept it straight.  That's why we, like the family, we're able to inherit this and enjoy it.  And, you know, we all live from this, so we appreciate that.
Yeah.
So family is very important to me, definitely.
So is family a big element of African life?  Yes, it is.
Because here, families support each other all the time, and we all live together as one, so this is how we're raised and brought up.  So, it is very important.
So, if there was one word you could say to people in the diaspora, what would it be?

Well, I just have to say, come back home, you know.  Come back home.  There's no way like home, you know.  Going abroad, doing things there, you know, you're still not from there.  It doesn't matter how much money you have and, you know, whatever you've established, you're still not from there.  So home is where the heart is, and I think people can make it here.  So definitely everyone, you need to come back home and establish.  Yeah.
